metadata.title: PVDF/palygorskite composite ultrafiltration membranes: Effects of nano- clay particles on membrane structure and properties

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Applied Clay Science

Research paper
PVDF/palygorskite composite ultrafiltration membranes: Effects of nanoclay particles on membrane structure and properties Dongyang Weia,b, Shouyong Zhoub,⁎, Meisheng Lib, Ailian Xueb, Yan Zhangb, Yijiang Zhaob,⁎, Jing Zhonga, Dawei Yangb,c a Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Advanced Catalytic Materials and Technology, School of Petrochemical Engineering, Changzhou University, No. 1 Gehu Road, Changzhou 213164, Jiangsu Province, PR China b Jiangsu Key Laboratory for Chemistry of Low-Dimensional Materials, Jiangsu Engineering Laboratory for Environmental Functional Materials, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Huaiyin Normal University, No. 111 West Changjiang Road, Huaian 223300, Jiangsu Province, PR China c Jiangsu Thinkre Membrane Material Co.,Ltd, No. 111 Jinnan Industrial Concentration Zone, Jinhu 211622, Jiangsu Province, PR China
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Palygorskite Polyvinylidene fluoride Composite membrane Ultrafiltration Antifouling property
A B S T R A C T
Palygorskite (PGS) was incorporated into a polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) matrix and PVDF/PGS nanocomposite UF membranes were prepared successfully via a combination of non-solvent-induced phase separation (NIPS) and thermally-induced phase separation (TIPS) processes. The influence of the size of the PGS particles (PGS-L, 450 nm and PGS-S, 302 nm) on the membrane pore structure, morphology, mechanical strength, filtration performance and antifouling property were investigated. The results showed that the PVDF/PGS-S composite membranes had higher porosity and lower overall membrane thickness and skin layer thickness. This directly resulted in better PWF, BSA flux, BSA rejection and FRR for the membranes loaded with PGS-S, when compared with the characteristics of PVDF/ PGS-L membranes. Thus, the physical structures are dominant factors in determining the separation performance of PVDF/PGS composite membranes. However, the surface roughness and thermal stability of PVDF/PGS-L membranes were greater than those of PVDF/PGS-S membranes and their surface was also more hydrophilic. Moreover, they exhibited higher mechanical strength owing to stronger binding forces and lower porosity. Thus, the composite properties of PVDF/PGS UF membranes could be adjusted by controlling the scale of the inorganic filler.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) has been widely used in ultrafiltration (UF) because of its extraordinary characteristics, including its excellent physical and chemical stability, mechanical strength and high solubility in common organic solvents such as N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP), dimethylformamide (DMF), dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO) and N, N-dimethyl acetamide (DMAc) (Bottino et al., 1991). However, the hydrophobicity of this polymer material leads directly to high surface fouling, and then further causes the attenuation of permeability.
Blending of inorganic nanoparticles with PVDF has attracted considerable attention because it is a simple process that can significantly improve membrane permeability, tension and antibiotic properties (Ayyaru and Ahn, 2017). Representative inorganic nanoparticles, e.g. TiO2 (Rahimpour et al., 2011; Shao et al., 2014; Su et al., 2009; Aloulou et al., 2018), Al2O3 (Lu et al., 2006), zeolite (He et al., 2014; Liao et al., 2011), Ag (Li et al., 2014; Li et al., 2013), silicate (Lai et al., 2014a; Thakur et al., 2014; Rubio et al., 2015), carbon nanotubes (CNTs)
(Moslehyani et al., 2015; Zhang et al., 2014), graphene oxide (GO) (Chang et al., 2014; Meng et al., 2016) etc. have been selected for incorporation into the polymeric matrix. It is true that the above studies have demonstrated the incorporation of filler materials could adjust structure and enhance physicochemical properties (e.g. porosity, hydrophilicity, thermal and mechanical stability) of composite membranes. However, the main advantages of each type of filler are limited. For example, Ag particles are more inclined to improve the antibacterial performance of membrane. In addition, some materials also need to be modified to reflect their properties. Again for instance, for those hydrophobic fillers such as CNTs, a common strategy is that generating hydroxyl and carboxyl groups on the surface by the way of acid treatment to improve dispersion (Yin and Deng, 2015). Among the various inorganic nanoparticles, natural nanofiber-like palygorskite (PGS) clay has also been used as a filler for membranes (Lai et al., 2014b; Shi et al., 2013; Zhang et al., 2013a, 2013b; Dlamini et al., 2019; Hosseini et al., 2019) because of its low cost, one-dimensional rod structure, high specific surface area and varied functional groups

(e.g., Mg–OH, Al–OH and Si–OH) (Zhang et al., 2013a, 2013b; Zhang et al., 2019). For example, Wu et al. prepared composite nanofiltration membranes using attapulgite (ATP, another name for PGS) nano-rods as the inorganic filler, thereby causing an enhancement in pure water flux and antifouling performance (Wu et al., 2017). Zhang et al. reported that the hydrophilicity, thermal stability and fouling resistance were improved greatly by incorporating ATP into PVDF ultrafiltration membranes (Zhang et al., 2014). Shokri et al. prepared PSf/clay nanocomposite membranes and found that they exhibited excellent adsorption capacity for As (V) solutions (Shokri et al., 2016).
In our previous work, we have demonstrated that the incorporation of original PGS nano-clay particles into PVDF not only improved the permeability, but also enhanced the anti-wearing property of membranes (Ji et al., 2015). We also modified PGS with a thermo-responsive monomer (poly N-isopropylacrylamide). The results showed that the thermo-responsive nanocomposite (modified PGS) was introduced into PVDF membranes successfully (Cai et al., 2016). In all, the addition of PGS with its one-dimensional rod structure could substantially enhance membrane performance. However, these previous studies were mainly focused on the effect of surface chemical structures (e.g. surface grafting) of PGS on the membrane performance. Most interestingly, rod-like PGS crystals with diameters of about 100–500 nm and lengths of 1–2 μm (Zou et al., 2018) are very similar to the scale of the UF membrane separation layer, which is generally<2 μm. Hence, it is necessary to find the optimal match between the scale of the PGS particles and the scale of the membrane separation layer. The effects of the physical structure of PGS (e.g., the length-to-diameter ratio) on the membrane structure and, further, the membrane performance are also very important.
In this study, PVDF/PGS composite ultrafiltration membranes were fabricated via a combination of non-solvent-induced phase separation (NIPS) and thermally-induced phase separation (TIPS) processes. The effects of incorporating PGS particles of different lengths on the structure and performance of the membranes were investigated. X-ray diffraction (XRD), Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM) were used to characterize membrane chemistry and physical structure. Membrane antifouling was also studied.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text: The PVDF polymer (Kynar®K-761, MW=440,000Da, ρ=1.79 g/cm3), the membrane raw material, was purchased from Elf Atochem. PGS slurry (solvent: water, solid content: 5%) was supplied by Xuyi Oubaite Clay Material Co. (China) and freeze-dried to a powder before use. Reagents including triethyl phosphate (TEP), polyethylene glycol (PEG-400, Mw=400Da) and bovine serum albumin (BSA, molecular biology grade) were all analytically pure and purchased from Aladdin Industrial Co. (China). The PVDF polymer and PGS powder were dried at 120 °C for 2 h before use.

sections.heading: 2.2. Fabrication of the PVDF/PGS composite membranes
sections.text:
The PVDF/PGS composite membranes were fabricated via a combination of non-solvent-induced phase separation and thermally-induced phase separation processes with TEP as the solvent and deionized water (DI water) as the non-solvent. Compositions of the casting solution are listed in detail in Table 1. Firstly, appropriate amounts of the PGS powder (0, 1, 4 and 7wt% based on the weight of the PVDF powder) were dispersed in TEP using a supersonic instrument (FS1200 N, Shanghai Shengxi Supersonic Instrument Co., Ltd.). Next, 19.05 wt% of PVDF powder was added to the PGS-TEP mixture and stirred at 80 °C for 24 h, and then 4.76 wt% of PEG-400 were added until a uniform and stable system was formed. The prepared casting solutions were maintained at 80 °C in the drying oven for another 24 h
with the purpose of removing bubbles. Each casting solution was coated on a clean glass plate using a film coating machine (Elcometer 4340, Elcometer, UK) with a 200-μm air gap at room temperature. The primary membrane together with the glass plate was immersed in DI water quickly, when the film coating machine was set at 80 °C and the relative humidity was 60%. The PGS/PVDF nanocomposite membranes were prepared after water exchange for 2 days.

sections.heading: 2.3.1. Particle size analysis and zeta potential measurements
sections.text: Both the particle size and zeta potential of PGS were measured using a nanometer particle size meter (ZETA SIZER, Nano series, Malvern). Before measuring particle size, trace of PGS power was prepared into an extremely dilute suspension liquid by ultrasonic method at room temperature, testing with a small amount of supernatant and the size distribution by intensity was recorded.

sections.heading: 2.3.2. Crystalline structures of the membranes
sections.text: The crystalline structures of all of the membrane samples and the PGS powders were investigated using an XRD system (ARLX'TRA, Switzerland) with a source (Cu Kα radiation) intensity of 45 kV/40mA. All samples were characterized in the scanning range of 5° < 2θ < 80°.

sections.heading: 2.3.3. Functional groups of the nanoparticles
sections.text: FTIR spectrometry (Nicolet iS50) was used to study the functional groups of the PGS nanoparticles in the range of 500–4000 cm−1.

sections.heading: 2.3.4. Surface compositions of the membranes
sections.text: The surface chemical compositions of the prepared membranes were investigated using XPS (Perkin-Elmer PHI 5000C ESCA, USA) with MgKα as the radiation resource.

sections.heading: 2.3.5. Membrane morphology
sections.text: The surface and cross-sectional morphologies of all membranes were analyzed by SEM (QUANTA FEG450). The cross-sections of the membranes were made brittle by immersion in liquid nitrogen and were coated with gold by sputtering. The overall thicknesses and skin layer thicknesses of the membranes were obtained from the SEM images using Image-Pro Plus 7.0 (Media Cybernetics, USA).

sections.heading: 2.3.6. Membrane surface roughness
sections.text: The surface roughness of all membranes was investigated by atomic force microscopy (AFM, Bruker, USA). The images were used to calculate the average roughness (Ra), root average square of Z data (Rq) and the maximum difference between the highest peak and the lowest valley (Rz) for a scan area of 3.3× 3.0 μm.

sections.heading: 2.3.7. Hydrophilicity, porosity and pore size of the membranes
sections.text:

Each sample was measured at five different points and the average value was calculated.
Membrane overall porosity was determined by the method of drywet weight. Wet membranes were gently wiped with lens wiping paper to remove the water on the membrane surface, and then left at room temperature overnight to dry completely. sections.heading: 3.1. Characterization of PGS particles of different sizes
sections.text:
The crystal and chemical structures of PGS-L and PGS-S were characterized using XRD and FTIR. As shown in Fig. 1(a), the diffraction peak of strongest intensity at 8.36°, which correspond to (110) plane, appeared in both PGS spectra. The diffraction peaks at 2θ values of 13.74°, 16.34°, 19.35°, 24.30°, 27.52°, 34.26°and 35.15° are apparent and correspond to the reflections of the (200), (130), (0 4 0), (221), (4 0 0), (0 6 1) and (1 6 1) planes, respectively. The crystal structures of the two PGS samples are consistent with those reported in the literature (Xu
et al., 2013). Also, no obvious differences in the characteristic FTIR peaks of PGS were found in Fig. 1 (b). The broad bands centered at around 3432 cm – 1 and 3551 cm – 1 can be ascribed to the stretching vibration of the magnesium hydroxyl group (Mg–OH) and silicon hydroxyl group (Si–OH), respectively. In addition, the band at about 1634 cm–1, which can be assigned to the –OH bending vibration of zeolitic water molecules, exists in the PGS porous channel.
The morphologies and particle size distributions of the two types of PGS are shown in Fig. 2. Both PGS-L (Fig. 2(a)) and PGS-S (Fig. 2(b)) have nano-rod structures of obviously different lengths, the TEM images of PGSL and PGS-S (Fig. 2(a´) and Fig. 2(b´)) can also verify this point. In addition, as can be seen in Fig. 2(c), the particle size distributions of PGS-L and PGS-S are centered around 450 and 302 nm, respectively. The results for the zeta potential of the two types of PGS are shown in Fig. 2 (d); both PGS-L and PGS-S were found to have negative zeta potentials, and the zeta
potential of the former was higher than that of the latter. And finally, it can be observed that PGS-L has higher BET surface area and pore volume than PGS-S (see Fig. 2 (e)). Hence, the above analyses suggested that PGSL and PGS-S have parallel chemical structures and the only difference is the size of the nano-rods.

sections.heading: 3.2. Chemical and structural characteristics of the prepared membranes
sections.text:
The XRD patterns of the PVDF membranes mixed with different
amounts of PGS are shown in Fig. 3 (a).The representative diffraction peak of PGS at about 8.36° can be seen in all of the PVDF/PGS composite membranes. The intensity of the diffraction peaks shows a tendency to strengthen with increasing PGS content. The peaks of the original membrane at 18.59°, 19.85° and 26.67°, which represent the (020), (1 1 0) and (021) planes of the α-phase PVDF crystal (Shi et al., 2012), also appear at the same locations for the composite membranes. Meanwhile, the PVDF peaks at 18.59° became wider gradually with increasing PGS content, which may be due to the PGS peak at 19.35°. Overall, compared with the original membrane, the membranes incorporating different lengths of PGS displayed very similar XRD patterns except for the diffraction peak at 8.36°. Besides, from the XRD patterns of the PGS powders of different lengths (Fig. 1 (a)), the changes in length-to-diameter ratio had little effect on the crystal structures of PGS. As a result, the crystal structures of the PVDF membranes changed little when PGS nanofibers with different length-to-diameter ratios were added.
The elemental tests on the membrane surfaces are shown in Fig. 3 (b). Because of the very low contents of PGS, the pivotal peaks of the Si, Al and Mg elements, which should appear at 104 eV, 75 eV and 52 eV, respectively, do not appear for samples of the PVDF/PGS composite membranes (Wu et al., 2017). However, the spectra do show that fluorine (F) and carbon (C) are present in all of the membranes, while oxygen (O) can be found in PGS-L/P7 and PGS-S/P7 but not P0. It is obvious that the oxygen comes from PGS, which suggests the presence of PGS nano-clay in the membrane surfaces. It also implies that PGS and the casting solution were physically mixed.
Fig. 3 (c) shows the thermogravimetric (TG) curves of the original membrane and the PVDF/PGS composite membranes. The thin lines in the Fig. 3 (c) are the partial enlarged drawing of the TG curves at around thermal decomposition temperature Td (temperature at 97% surplus of the membrane). It can be found that the Td of the P0, PGS-L/ P1, PGS-S/P1, PGS-L/P4, PGS-S/P4, PGS-L/P7 and PGS-S/P7 were 412.3 °C, 418.7 °C, 413.5 °C, 423.1 °C, 422.1 °C, 431.1 °C and 428.3 °C, respectively. Both PGS-L and PGS-S enhanced the Td. This means that the addition of PGS to the PVDF matrix brings about an improvement in thermal stability, due to the uniform distribution of PGS nano-clay in the polymer network and the interactions between the polymer chains and the groups on the surface of the membranes (Zhang et al., 2014). Besides, the Td values of the PVDF/PGS-L membranes were all higher than those of PGS-S at the same content, which reveals that the greater physical length is more likely to be associated with a higher thermal decomposition temperature. The mechanism of which can be explained as follows. In fact, the TG analysis is actually a calcining process in which both the PVDF matrix and PGS are calcined. Own to the larger physical size, it needs higher temperature to break the chemical bond of PGS-L. Hence, the Td values of the PVDF/PGS-L membranes were higher than those of PGS-S. Thus, the introduction of different sizes of PGS into the PVDF matrix may affect the membrane thermal stability.

sections.heading: 3.3. Surface physical structures of the prepared membranes
3.3.1. Membrane morphology
sections.text:
SEM images of the top surfaces and cross-sections of the prepared membranes are shown in Figs. 4 and 5, respectively. As can be seen in Fig. 5, all of the membranes have an asymmetric structure that includes a skin layer on the top surface that is a selective layer, finger-like voids underneath the skin layer and a spongy structure as the bottom layer. Fig. 4 shows that the diversity on the top surface was not significantly different for incorporation of PGS of different lengths. Also, no PGS was exposed on the top surface of any of the membranes, however, it can be seen in the finger-like pore structure (see the red ellipses in Fig. 5). In fact, PGS was only wedged or tiled on the surface and did not form a strong interaction with the PVDF polymer during the period of precipitation. Hence, it was likely to break away from the PVDF polymer into the DI water. On the other hand, exchange of the solvent and non-
solvent can create convection between the two sides of the top surface of the membrane, which would cause PGS to be removed from the PVDF polymer. Based on the above two reasons, it is reasonable to believe that PGS is infrequently exposed on the membrane surface. In addition, larger holes appeared on the surfaces of the membranes with increased loadings of PGS as the finger-like void structures have been affected. As can be seen from the cross-sections of P0, PGS-L/P7 and PGS-S/P7 and higher magnifications in Fig. 5, the PGS nano-rods interspersed in the finger-like structural support, which leads to a rougher more porous structure when compared with P0. The EDS elemental analysis of the cross-section could further clarify this point. The EDS results demonstrate the existence of oxygen (O) and silicon (Si) element in the finger-like pore structure of PGS-L/P7 and PGS-S/P7 (Fig. 5), which means that the PGS is anchored in the cross-section. As a consequence, some macropores can be observed on the top surface of the membranes.
As can be observed in Table 1, when a PGS nano-clay was added, the overall thickness and skin layer thickness of the membrane decreased. This result is consistent with our previous work, the mechanisms of which have been given (Ji et al., 2015). In short, the added PGS increases the crystallinity of PVDF and the phase inversion rate at the top surface. In addition, for the same content of PGS (e.g. 7 wt%), the membrane loaded with PGS-S had a lower overall thickness and skin layer thickness compared with that loaded with PGS-L. When PGS-L and PGS-S were loaded into the PVDF polymer, both could act as nucleating agents and increase the crystallinity of PVDF, thereby resulting in a higher density of the PVDF membrane and eventually causing the reduction of the overall membrane thickness. For the overall membrane thickness, PGS-S has a smaller physical size, the amount of which would be more than PGS-L in unit space. Thus, the former would produce additional PVDF crystallinity and further reduce the overall membrane thickness. Besides, during the growth of spherocrystals, the most outstanding characteristic is the
occurrence of small-angle bifurcation, and it is precisely because of this small-angle bifurcation that the spherocrystals can completely fill the spherical space and keep the strip lamellar crystal parallel to the radius. In this study, the growing PVDF lamellar crystal rejected the PGS nanorods; however, PGS-L occupies a larger spatial zone, causing the angle of bifurcation to increase. As a result, the PVDF spherocrystal volume becomes larger, which leads to a higher overall membrane thickness for the membrane loaded with PGS-L. As a consequence, the above two factors give rise to PGS-S/P7 being thinner than PGS-L/P7, as shown in Table 1. Other membranes loaded with 1wt% and 4wt% of PGS display the same trends. However, compared with the original membrane, all of the PVDF/PGS composite membranes have a lower overall membrane thickness. Therefore, the increase in the overall membrane thickness caused by the PVDF spherocrystal volume becoming larger is not the dominant factor, and does not alter the trend of the overall membrane thickness being reduced with PGS loading. For the membrane skin thickness, it is suspected that the additional PGS-S in the unit space increased the liquid-liquid demixing rate at the surface of the polymer solution, which further reduced the membrane skin thickness, hence the skin thickness of the membrane loaded with PGS-S displayed a lower value than that loaded with PGS-L.

sections.heading: 3.3.2. Membrane surface roughness
sections.text:
The effect of PGS size on the membrane surface roughness is shown in Fig. 6. The scan area is 3 μm×3 μm. The bright and dark areas in the images represent the higher points and valleys of the membrane top surface, respectively. The specific surface roughness parameters (including Ra, Rq, and Rz) were determined and the results are shown in Table 1. It can be found that the root average square of Z data (Rq) values of the P0, PGS-L/P1, PGS-S/P1, PGS-L/P4, PGS-S/P4, PGS-L/P7 and PGS-S/P7 were 22.7 nm, 27.9 nm, 25.1 nm, 31.6 nm, 27.4 nm, 32.6 nm and 28.7 nm, respectively. Compared with the Rq of P0, all of the PVDF/PGS composite membranes were rougher. This means that the surface roughness of PVDF/PGS composite membranes improved upon embedding of PGS. Moreover, the Rq values of all of the membranes loaded with PGS-L exceeded those of membranes loaded with PGS-S. According to the previous analysis of the SEM images of the membrane top surfaces, owing to the weaker binding forces on the membrane surface and faster exchange rate between the solvent and non-solvent, the PGS nano-rods did not effectively tile on the top surface of the membrane, most were embedded under the skin layer at random angles. Thus, the Rq of PGS-L/P7 was only 9.9 nm larger than that of P0. When PGS-L was loaded into the PVDF polymer, the longer
nano-rods were more likely to puncture the skin layer during polymer precipitation and form a mountain/peak-like surface morphology. In addition, electrostatic interactions among the surface polymer chains were another key factor for membrane surface roughness. Stronger electrostatic interactions produce greater surface roughness (Esmaeili
et al., 2010). As presented above, the zeta potential of PGS-L nano-clay is higher than that of PGS-S nano-clay (see Fig. 2 (d)). Stronger interactions among polymer chains could form when PGS-L was loaded, thereby leading to a wrinkling and deforming polymer matrix on the top surface.

sections.heading: 3.3.3. Pore size distribution and porosity
sections.text:
The pore size distributions of PGS-L/P7 and PGS-S/P7 are provided in Fig.7. Table 1 summarizes the mean pore size and porosity information for the original membrane and the PVDF/PGS composite membranes. The mean pore sizes of all samples are in the range 24–28 nm. Compared with the original membrane, the pore sizes of all composite membranes were slightly higher and these results are consistent with the SEM images. That is because the number of bigger voids increases with the loading of PGS. The rod crystal length of PGS in Ji's work (Ji et al., 2015) is similar to that of PGS-L, in their work, the mean pore sizes of samples are mainly in the range 24–31 nm. This is basically consistent with our experimental results. Besides, the membranes loaded with PGS-S are more inclined to have larger pore sizes compared with those loaded with PGS-L. According to Ji et al. (2015), the competition between contraction and precipitation of the surrounding polymer solution accounts for the final pore size. Specifically, the rates of solvent/non-solvent exchange and PVDF crystallization are the key factors. As discussed previously, when PGS-S is loaded into the PVDF polymer, the increased concentration in unit space facilitates the process of PVDF crystallization and increases the rate of solvent/non-solvent exchange. This leads to polymer precipitation gaining the upper hand and larger pore sizes forming. Meanwhile, as can be seen in Table 1, the porosities of the membranes loaded with PGS are larger than that of P0. Moreover, the porosities of the membranes loaded PGSS are larger than those of the membranes loaded with PGS-L. The addition of PGS-S to the PVDF polymer is more beneficial in increasing
PVDF crystallization and improving the network structure, thereby forming a more porous support layer and increasing the porosity.

sections.heading: 3.3.4. Mechanical properties
sections.text: The tensile strengths of the prepared membranes are reported in Fig. 8. The tensile strengths of PGS-L/P7 and PGS-S/P7 are 1.89 and 1.67MPa, respectively. It is obvious that the loading of PGS-L improved the tensile strength of the prepared membranes. Meanwhile, the tensile strengths of the other membranes loaded with 1 wt% and 4wt% were all lower. The tensile strength increase with PGS loading can be explained by the enhanced binding force between the well-dispersed PGS nano-clay and the PVDF polymer. As discussed above, the PGS active surface can bind to the polymer chains and form a cross-linked structure. PGS provides the cross-linking points. When a tensile stress is applied at one polymer chain, the binding force will transmit it to other polymer chains crosswise through the cross-linking points, dissipating the impact energy (Peng et al., 2009). To use a vivid metaphor, adding PGS to the PVDF polymer is just like the process of building a house; PGS can be likened to the steel frame: the more complete the steel frame, the more stable the house. When PGS-L is added to the casting solution, it is more conducive to forming stronger binding forces with polymer and enhancing the tensile strength because of the larger BET surface area of its particles. In addition, from the porosity analysis in Table 1, the loading of PGS-S increases the porosity of the membrane, thereby reducing the membrane tensile strength more or less.

sections.heading: 3.4. Ultrafiltration performances of the prepared membranes
3.4.1. Hydrophilicity of the membranes
sections.text: The dynamic contact angles of the membranes were measured and the results can be seen in Fig. 9. The two important factors affecting the contact angle are the surface chemical structure and the roughness of the top surface. The initial contact angles of the membranes loaded with PGS were all lower than that of P0 (see Fig. 9 (a)). As a hydrophilic inorganic nanoparticle, the exposed PGS nano-clay can improve the membrane hydrophilicity because of its hydrophilic hydroxyl groups. On the other hand, PGS nano-clay loading can increase the membrane surface roughness (see Table 1). As is well known, an increase in membrane surface roughness can reduce the contact angle. Hence, both PGS-L and PGS-S can improve the hydrophilicity of the membrane. The interesting result is that PGS-L increases the hydrophilicity more than PGS-S (see Fig. 9 (b)). That is because of the greater surface roughness and additional quantities of exposed PGS of the former.

sections.heading: 3.4.2. Separation properties of the prepared membranes
sections.text:
In order to investigate the effect of loading different lengths of PGS particles on the membrane permeability, the pure water flux (PWF) was determined and the results can be seen in Fig. 10. It is obvious that the stable PWF increased from 158.3 L/m2 h for the original PVDF membrane to 260.7 L/m2 h for PGS-L/P7 and 279.2 L/m2 h for PGS-S/P7. The reason for the stable PWF enhancement has been discussed in our previous work (Ji et al., 2015); it is mainly due to changes in the physical and chemical structures of the membrane skin. In contrast to Zhang's study (Zhang et al., 2019), the contact angles of our membranes are all above 80° and not as hydrophilic as their membranes, but the PWFs of ours are significantly higher than theirs (the highest is 47.2 L/ m2 h). Besides, it has been found that the PWF of AT-7 (PVDF membrane added 7wt% of PGS) in Ji's work is 260.5 L/m2 h, the result of which is very close to PGS-L/P7, but lower than PGS-S/P7. This is mainly due to the stronger anti-fouling performance of the PVDF membrane loaded with PGS-S, and the specific reasons will be discussed in detail in the following. However, in this work, the focus is on the effect of the nanoscale PGS on the membrane performances. From Fig.10, all of the membranes with a loading of PGS-S have higher PWFs than those of the membranes loaded with PGS-L. Apart from the addition of 4 wt%, other PVDF composite membranes loaded with PGS-S
had higher mean pore sizes than those loaded with PGS-L, and a similar result was obtained for the porosity (see Table 1). Furthermore, the skin layer thickness is another major factor affecting PWF. It is known that under a certain pressure, a thicker skin layer will produce greater transmembrane resistance, and hence result in lower permeation. From Table 1, the membranes loaded with PGS-L had higher skin layer thicknesses than those loaded with PGS-S. Thus, the above two reasons result in a higher stable PWF for the PGS-S membranes.
On the other hand, all of the membranes exhibited a high BSA rejection. As can be seen in Fig. 11, the BSA rejections of the original and PVDF/PGS composite membranes all exceeded 99%. This means that the pore sizes of the prepared membranes reached the ultrafiltration level. Furthermore, it can also be observed that the performances of the membranes loaded with PGS-S were better than those of the membranes loaded with PGS-L throughout the range of PGS loading contents. It is interesting that the mean pore sizes of the membranes loaded with PGS-S all exceeded those of membranes loaded with PGS-L, except for those with 4wt% loading content. In fact, the separation property is mainly affected by the skin layer of the membrane, including the pore structure and the surface properties. An increased mean pore size negatively impacts solute trapping. As the membranes loaded with PGS-L had higher values of surface roughness (see Table 1), they were more likely to be contaminated, leading to a reduction of solute rejection (Lu et al., 2006). It is reasonable to believe that the surface property of the skin layer plays a major role in protein filtration. Also, these results can be further explained by the BSA flux. As can be seen in Fig. 11, all of the membranes loaded with PGS-L and PGS-S display an increase in BSA flux, whereas the acceleration decreased with increasing loading content. This means that a certain factor has limited the increase in BSA flux rate when more PGS nano-clay has been loaded. As discussed above, a weaker interaction and exchange between solvent and non-solvent could lead to the loss of PGS nano-clay, and the PGS would reach saturation on the top membrane surface with increasing PGS content. Meanwhile, the surface roughness would increase with increasing PGS content, which would increase membrane pollution. Therefore, the surface roughness plays a major role in protein rejection, and the membranes loaded with PGS-L exhibit lower BSA rejection.

sections.heading: 3.4.3. Antifouling performances of the prepared membranes
sections.text: In order to investigate the effect of loading different lengths of PGS on the antifouling performance of the composite membranes, a BSA solution with a concentration of 1000 ppm was prepared to pollute the membranes. The flux recovery ratio (FRR) was calculated as the evaluation criterion and the results are shown in Fig. 12. When the PGS nano-clay was loaded into the PVDF polymer, the PVDF/PGS composite membranes displayed a higher FRR, which can be attributed to an improvement in membrane surface hydrophilicity. Moreover, FRRs for the membranes loaded with PGS-L were all lower than those loaded with PGS-S. This may be because the former has a greater surface roughness that causes the foulant to readily accumulate in the valleys of the membrane surface, and also makes it more difficult to remove. Therefore, the membranes loaded with PGS-S can be more easily regenerated.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text: The effects of nano-clay PGS on the membrane structures and properties were studied in detail in this work. The PVDF/PGS composite membranes loaded with PGS-S had higher porosities and lower overall membrane thicknesses and skin layer thicknesses. Meanwhile, the membranes loaded with PGS-L had greater thermal stability. However, the crystal structures of the PVDF/PGS composite membranes were hardly affected by the scale of the PGS particles. The membrane surface roughness when loaded with PGS-L was larger than that of membranes loaded with PGS-S and the surface was also more hydrophilic. Moreover, PGS-L membranes exhibited greater mechanical strength owing to a stronger binding force and lower porosity. The PWF and BSA flux of the PVDF/PGS composite membranes all increased significantly with the loading of PGS, but the BSA rejection almost keeps constant. The PWF, BSA flux, BSA rejection and FRR values of the membranes loaded with PGS-S were superior to those of the membranes loaded with PGS-L. The physical structures, e.g. porosity, overall membrane thickness and skin layer thickness, were the dominant factors determining the separation performances of PVDF/PGS composite membranes.

metadata.abstractText: Palygorskite (PGS) was incorporated into a polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) matrix and PVDF/PGS nanocomposite UF membranes were prepared successfully via a combination of non-solvent-induced phase separation (NIPS) and thermally-induced phase separation (TIPS) processes. The influence of the size of the PGS particles (PGS-L, 450 nm and PGS-S, 302 nm) on the membrane pore structure, morphology, mechanical strength, filtration performance and antifouling property were investigated. The results showed that the PVDF/PGS-S composite membranes had higher porosity and lower overall membrane thickness and skin layer thickness. This directly resulted in better PWF, BSA flux, BSA rejection and FRR for the membranes loaded with PGS-S, when compared with the characteristics of PVDF/ PGS-L membranes. Thus, the physical structures are dominant factors in determining the separation performance of PVDF/PGS composite membranes. However, the surface roughness and thermal stability of PVDF/PGS-L membranes were greater than those of PVDF/PGS-S membranes and their surface was also more hydrophilic. Moreover, they exhibited higher mechanical strength owing to stronger binding forces and lower porosity. Thus, the composite properties of PVDF/PGS UF membranes could be adjusted by controlling the scale of the inorganic filler.
